sentence: Home improvement warehouse operators The Home Depot, Inc. ( HD ) and Lowe's Companies, Inc. ( LOW ) were both downgraded on Thursday by analysts at JMS Research, which cited several macroeconomic concerns.
The firm cut its rating on HD and LOW from "Buy" to "Neutral," noting that "We believe the housing market recovery remains elusive and slower than anticipated.
Much of the recent 1Q comp boost was driven by government stimulus and better weather, which we believe will wear off, resulting in slower sales.
A variety of macro indicators, including home prices, unemployment, and consumer credit all point in the same negative direction."

Continuing, JMS said "We believe that HD, in particular, does have significant margin drivers to offset some of the sales slowdown, but we fear that a return to negative comps is possible and would keep the stock range-bound regardless of modest earnings growth.
Additionally, for LOW, we are concerned about their investment in inventory and labor ahead of a recovery that we do not see likely in 2010."
Home Depot shares fell 22 cents, or -0.7%, while Lowe's shares fell 29 cents, or -1.3%, in premarket trading Thursday.
Shares of HD have a dividend yield of 3.08%, based on last night's closing stock price of $30.50.
Shares of LOW have a dividend yield of 2.01%, based on last night's closing stock price of $21.85.
Neither The Home Depot, Inc. ( HD ) nor Lowe's Companies, Inc. ( LOW ) are currently recommended, with both stocks holding a Dividend.com DARSâ„¢ Rating of 3.4 out of 5 stars.
